docs.title: Home
docs.text: This is the documentation for Low-Ops platform. Here you will find information about how to use the platform. It describes the platform's architecture and how to use it as a developer and as an operator.

docs.title: Internal Developer Platform
docs.text: Low-Ops is a platform for running applications in a cloud environment. It is designed to be easy to use and to require minimal maintenance. At its core, it is a Kubernetes cluster with a set of tools to make it easy to deploy and manage applications. It is designed to be used by developers and operators with minimal knowledge of Kubernetes and cloud infrastructure. You will be able to do all your tasks through the Low-Ops Portal supported with best practices of delivering applications to your business and customers.

docs.title: Focus on value delivery. Not re-inventing the wheel.
docs.text: Without Low-Ops, an organization would need to hire a team of DevOps-, Cloud engineers and Platform engineers to build and maintain a platform for running applications. This is a costly and time-consuming process. Low-Ops solves this problem by providing a platform that is easy to use and requires minimal maintenance. This allows organizations to focus on their core business and deliver value to their customers.

docs.title: Key features
docs.text:
• Easy to use - Low-Ops is designed to be easy to use. It is designed to be used by developers and operators with minimal knowledge of Kubernetes and cloud infrastructure. You will be able to do all your tasks through the Low-Ops Portal.
  • Self-service - Low-Ops is designed to be self-service. This means that developers and operators can do all their tasks without having to contact a platform team.
  • Self-healing - Low-Ops is designed to be self-healing. This means that if something goes wrong, the platform will automatically fix itself.
  • Highly available - Low-Ops is designed to be highly available. This means that if something goes wrong, the platform will automatically recover from the failure.
  • Cost-effective - Low-Ops is designed to be cost-effective. This means that it is designed to be cheap to run and maintain.
  • Secure - Low-Ops is designed to be secure. This means that it is designed to be secure by default. With fine-grained permission access, users can only access what they need to do their job.
  • Scalable - Low-Ops is designed to be scalable. This means that it is designed to be able to scale up and down as needed.
  • Upgradable - Low-Ops is designed to be upgradable. This means that it is designed to be able to upgrade to new versions of Kubernetes and other components without downtime.

Jump to Getting Started to learn how to use Low-Ops with Mendix. Or checkout out our Architecture to learn how Low-Ops works.

docs.title: Activities
docs.text: Activity tab is designed for recording events and actions within the system for the purpose of Monitoring, Analyzing, and Ensuring accountability.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Activity tab captures information about activities such as: - Application onboarding - Application configuration changes - Data backups and restore actions - Application pipeline triggers on commits to repository - Other significant events within the platform or applications

docs.title: Accessing Activity tab
docs.text:
1. Select an application from the list and click on it to open.
  2. You will be redirected to the "Overview" tab which shows the recent activity.
  1. To access the full activities list, you have two options:

a. Click on "All activities" in the right corner of the Overview tab.

b. Navigate to the "Activity" tab.

  1. In the Activities section, you will find the following information for each audit log event:
  2. Status
  3. Description
  4. Triggered by
  5. Environment
  6. Date and time

Note: Regular review of Activity can help maintain security, track changes, and ensure compliance with organizational policies.

docs.title: Settings
docs.text: Settings page allows to offboard an application.

docs.title: Accesing "Settings" tab
docs.text:
1. From the "Home" page, select an application.
  2. Navigate to the "Settings" tab.

NOTE: To learn how to offboard an application, follow the steps from the Offboard tutorial.

docs.title: Source
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to access and use the "Source" tab, including instructions on how to connect private projects in Version Control System (Gitea) using Mendix Studio Pro.

docs.title: Accessing the Source Tab
docs.text:
1. From the "Home" page, select an application.
  2. Navigate to the "Source" tab.

docs.title: Connecting with Mendix Studio Pro
docs.text:
The source page contains the Git repository URL to use in the Mendix Studio Pro.

Note: For instructions on logging into Mendix Studio Pro, refer to the Mendix tutorial.

docs.title: Opening project in the Version Control System (VCS)
docs.text:
To open the project in the Version Control System:

  1. Click the "Open in Gitea" button.
  2. You will be redirected to the project in the VCS.

docs.title: Viewing Branch List and Commit History
docs.text:
The Source page provides information about commits and branches:

  1. View the number of commits and branches at the top of the page.

  2. To see the list of branches:

  3. Locate the branch dropdown menu.

  4. Click the arrow to open the dropdown.
  5. View the list of branches.
  6. Select a branch to navigate to it.

Tip: Regularly review your branches and commit history to maintain a clear understanding of your project's development progress.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use meaningful branch names to easily identify the purpose of each branch.
  • Regularly merge or delete old branches to keep your repository clean.
  • Use Gitea for more detailed code reviews and collaboration.

docs.title: Build
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to access and understand the "Build" tab.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Build page allows you to view and manage build versions, providing insight into your application's development history and enabling you to track changes over time.

docs.title: Accessing the Build Tab
docs.text:
1. From the "Home" page, select an application.
  2. Navigate to the "Build" tab.

docs.title: Understanding Build Components
docs.text:
The Build tab contains several key components:

  1. Package: Indicates the package name
  2. Commit: Indicates the Commit name
  3. Security Severity: Identifies and categorizes potential security issues within each build

    Note: To learn more about the security report, refer to the Security Report tutorial.

  4. Policies: Pre-defined rules that validate Mendix app development against best practices

    Note: To learn more about the policies, refer to the Code Quality tutorial.

  5. Description: Indicates the name of the environment
  6. Mendix Version: Shows the version of Mendix used
  7. Created At: Date and time when the application was created

docs.title: Making Adjustments
docs.text:
To access additional options:

  1. Click the arrow to open the menu

  2. In this menu, you can:

    • Deploy the application

      Note: To learn how to deploy an application, refer to the Deploy tutorial.

    • Modify the "Description"
    • Open the Security Severity details
    • Open the Policies details

docs.title: Modifying the Description
docs.text:
1. Click on "Description"
  2. In the pop-up window, adjust the description
  3. Click the save button

Tip: Regularly review and update build descriptions to maintain clear documentation of your application versions.

docs.title: Code Quality
docs.text: This document provides an overview of the Policies feature in your Mendix applications and instructions on how to access and interpret policy test results.

docs.title: Understanding Policies
docs.text: Policies are a set of pre-defined rules that validate Mendix app development against best practices. They help ensure code quality and adherence to development standards.

docs.title: Accessing Policy Details
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Build tab of your application.
  2. Locate the Policies section.
  3. Click on "Details" to access more comprehensive information about the Policies.

  4. In the Details view, you will see a summary of policy test results, including:

    • Total number of tests
    • Number of passed tests
    • Number of failed tests

5. To view details of the failed policies, click the arrow as shown in the screenshot.

docs.title: Interpreting Policy Results
docs.text:
• Passed Tests: These indicate areas where your application meets the defined best practices.
  • Failed Tests: These highlight areas that may need improvement to align with best practices.

Tip: Focus on addressing failed policy tests to improve the overall quality of your Mendix application.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Regularly review policy test results to maintain code quality.
  • Address failed policy tests as part of your development cycle.
  • Use policy results to guide team discussions on code quality and best practices.

Note: Consistently reviewing and addressing both Security Severity issues and Policy test results can significantly enhance the quality and security of your Mendix applications.

docs.title: Security Report
docs.text: This document provides an overview of the Security Severity feature in your Mendix applications and instructions on how to access detailed security information.

docs.title: Understanding Security Severity
docs.text: The Security Severity feature helps identify and categorize potential security issues within each build, allowing you to address vulnerabilities promptly.

docs.title: Accessing Security Severity Details
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Build tab of your application.

  2. Locate the Security Severity section.

  3. Click on "Details" to access more comprehensive information about the security issues detected in a specific build.
  4. Check the "Include image vulnerabilities" box to view security issues related to Docker images used in your application.
  5. In the Details view, you will see:
    • A summary of security vulnerabilities categorized by severity (High, Medium, Low)
    • A table listing specific vulnerabilities including their CVE IDs, affected packages, versions, and fixed versions

Note: Regularly reviewing Security Severity information can help maintain the security of your Mendix applications and address potential vulnerabilities in a timely manner.

docs.title: Interpreting Security Severity Information
docs.text:
• High Severity: These issues require immediate attention and should be addressed as soon as possible.
  • Medium Severity: These issues are important but may not require immediate action. They should be addressed in your next update cycle.
  • Low Severity: These issues pose minimal risk but should still be reviewed and addressed when convenient.

Tip: Always prioritize addressing high severity vulnerabilities to minimize potential security risks to your application. Don't forget to review Docker image vulnerabilities by checking the "Include image vulnerabilities" box.

docs.title: Access
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to access the Access tab and retrieve login credentials for Mendix Studio Pro and Mendix Debugger.

docs.title: Access tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select "Access".

docs.title: Mendix Studio Pro & Debugger Access
docs.text:
1. To login to Mendix Studio Pro:

    • Locate the Admin User section
    • Copy the application URL to access the page
    • Use the username and password to login

  2. To access Mendix Debugger via Mendix Studio Pro:

    • Locate the "Debugging" section
    • Copy the URL to access the page
    • Use the password to login

NOTE: Ensure you keep these credentials secure and do not share them with unauthorized individuals.

docs.title: Actions
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to Start, Stop, and Restart the application in different environments.

docs.title: Accessing the Start button
docs.text:
There are two ways to access the Start button:

  1. From the Environments page:
  2. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  3. Click the Start button next to the specific environment.

  1. From the Deployment page:
  2. Open a specific environment.
  3. You will be redirected to the Deployment page.
  4. Locate the Start button on this page.

docs.title: Starting the application
docs.text:
1. Click the Start button for the desired environment.
  2. The status will change to "Starting.
  3. Wait for 1-2 minutes while the application initializes.

  4. The status will change to "Running" once the application has started.

  5. Click the provided URL to verify that the application opens successfully.

docs.title: Accessing the Stop Button
docs.text:
The Stop button is located in the same place as the Start button. There are two ways to access it:

  1. From the Environments page:
  2. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  3. Click the Stop button next to the specific environment.

  1. From the Deployment page:
  2. Open a specific environment.
  3. You will be redirected to the Deployment page.
  4. Locate the Stop button on this page.

docs.title: Stopping the Application
docs.text:
1. Click the Stop button for the desired environment.
  2. The status will change to "Stopping".
  1. Wait for the application to fully stop.
  2. The status will change to "Stopped" once the application has been terminated.
  1. Attempting to access the URL should result in a "503 Service Temporarily Unavailable" error message.

docs.title: Accessing the Restart button
docs.text:
The Restart button is located in the same place as the Start and Stop button. There are two ways to access it:

  1. From the Environments page:
  2. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  3. Click the arrow to access drop down menu and see access the Restart button.

  1. From the Deployment page:
  2. Open a specific environment.
  3. You will be redirected to the Deployment page.
  4. Locate the Restart button by clicking the arrow and accessing the Restart button.

docs.title: Restarting the Application
docs.text:
1. Click the Restart button for the desired environment.
  2. The status will change to "Restarting".
  1. Wait for 1-2 minutes while the application initializes.
  2. The status will change to "Running" once the application has restarted.
  1. Click the provided URL to verify that the application opens successfully.

docs.title: Alerts
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to access the Alerts tab and understand the alert system for monitoring application health.

docs.title: Accesing the Alerts tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select "Alerts".

docs.title: Understanding Alerts
docs.text:
1. Locate the "Status" column
  2. This column indicates if the application is running without problems or if any issues have occurred

Note: Alerts serve as automated notifications that promptly inform operators about potential issues or deviations from normal behavior, enabling rapid response and resolution.

docs.title: Create
docs.text: This documentation provides a step by step guide on how to create new environments.

docs.title: Creating new environment
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  1. Click the "Create new environment" button.
  1. In the pop up window, indicate environment name and click the "Create" button.
  1. Allow a couple of minutes for the environment to create.
  1. Once the environment is created, it will appear in the list of environments.

NOTE: To learn how to deploy an application in the created environment, follow the steps from the Deploy tutorial.

docs.title: Deploy
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to deploy the application in different environments.

docs.title: Deploy the Application
docs.text: NOTE: The following steps are the same for Test, Acceptance and Production environments.

docs.title: Accessing the Deploy button
docs.text:
There are two ways to access the Deploy button:

  1. From the Environments page:
  2. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  3. Click the Start button next to the specific environment.

  1. From the Deployment page:
  2. Open a specific environment.
  3. You will be redirected to the Deployment page.
  4. Locate the Start button on this page.

docs.title: Deploying the Application
docs.text:
1. Once the "Deploy" button is clicked, a side menu will pop.
  2. Select the package version.
  3. Configure Constants; You can include and modify new values as needed by clicking the pencil.
  4. Enable/Disable MyFirstModule.Cleanup.
  5. Check the box for "I acknowledge the app might be offline briefly during deployment".

  6. Click the "Deploy" button.

  7. The status will change to "Deploying".

  1. Wait for 1-2 minutes while the application initializes.
  2. The status will change to "Running" once the application is deployed.

  1. Click the provided URL to verify that the application opens successfully.

docs.title: Firewall
docs.text: Firewall (IP filtering) serves to restrict application access to specific IP address or IP ranges.

docs.title: Accessing the Firewall Tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the "Environments" tab.
  2. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  3. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  4. In the left-side menu, select "Firewall".

docs.title: Creating a Firewall Rule
docs.text:
1. Click the "Create rule" button in the right corner.
  2. In the pop-up window, enter the rule details:
    • Indicate the path that should be denied or allowed for a specific IP address
    • Select the desired action from the drop-down menu: "Allow" or "Deny"
    • Input the IP adresses and press "ENTER".
    • Include description
    • Click the "Create" button
  3. Re-deploy the application by following the steps from the Deploy Application Tutorial.

docs.title: Updating a Firewall Rule
docs.text:
1. Return to the Firewall tab.
  2. Click on the three dots at the right corner of the rule you want to edit.
  3. Click the "Edit" button.
  4. In the pop window update the needed details.
  5. Click "Save" to apply the changes.

docs.title: Deleting a Firewall Rule
docs.text:
1. Return to the Firewall tab.
  2. Click on the three dots at the right corner of the rule you want to delete.
  3. Click the "Delete" button.
  4. Confirm the deletion in the pop-up window by clicking the "Delete" button.

docs.title: Logs
docs.text: Logs capture information about events, activities, errors, or status changes; they serve as a valuable resource for troubleshooting, debugging, and monitoring system performance.

docs.title: Accessing the Logs Tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select Logs.

docs.title: Configuring Log Levels
docs.text:
1. Click the "Configure Log Levels" button in the upper right corner.
  1. In the pop-up window, click the "Add log level" buton.
  1. Specify the Log node.
  2. Select Log level from the drop-down menu.
  3. Provide a Description if necessary.
  4. Click on the blue button to add the log level.
  5. Return to the Logs tab to review the traces.

NOTE: Re-deploy the application for changes to take effect. Re-deploy the application by following the steps from the Deploy Application Tutorial.

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text: Monitoring is essential for proactively identifying and addressing system issues, ensuring performance, and maintaining overall reliability with minimal manual intervention.

docs.title: Access Monitoring Tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the "Environments" tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select "Monitoring".

docs.title: Managing Monitoring tab
docs.text:
1. Select the period for which to display the metrics: "3H", "12H", "24H", or "48H".

  2. Click the "Open in Grafana" button to access more metrics.

docs.title: Mendix Runtime Requests (per second)
docs.text: This metric shows the number of requests processed by the Mendix Runtime per second.

docs.title: CPU Usage
docs.text: This metric displays the percentage of CPU utilization by the Mendix application.

docs.title: JVM Memory Usage
docs.text: This metric shows the amount of Java Virtual Machine (JVM) memory used by the application.

docs.title: Mendix Connection Bus
docs.text: This metric displays the status and performance of the Mendix Connection Bus.

docs.title: Microflow Metrics - Mendix Microflow Execution Frequency
docs.text: This metric displays Mendix Microflow Execution Frequency (per second).

docs.title: Microflow Metrics - Mendix Microflow Execution Time
docs.text: This metric displays Mendix Microflow Execution Time.

docs.title: Settings
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to view and modify environment settings.

docs.title: Access Settings tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the "Environments" tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select "Settings".

The Configuration page is divided into five sections: "Domain", "Scaling", "Environment Variables", "Runtime Settings", and "Delete this environment".

docs.title: "Domain" Section
docs.text: This section consists of the "Application URL", and fields for "TLS Certificate Chain" and "TLS Private Key".

docs.title: "Scaling" Section
docs.text:
This section allows you to modify "Quotas CPU", "Quotas memory", and "Replicas".

To make changes: - Update the fields with desired changes. - Click the "Save changes" button.

docs.title: "Environment Variables" Section
docs.text:
This section allows you to add new environment variables.

To add a new variable: 1. Click on the "Add" button in the right corner. 2. In the pop-up window: - Include the "Name", "Value", and "Description". - Check the "Protected" checkbox (optional). - Click on the "Add" button.

docs.title: "Runtime Settings" Section
docs.text:
This section allows you to add new runtime settings.

To add a new runtime settings:

  1. Click on the "Add" button in the right corner.
  2. In the pop-up window:
  3. Include the "Name" and "Value".
  4. Click on the "Add" button.

NOTE: For the new setting values to take effect, re-deploy the application. Re-deploy the application by following the steps from the Deploy Application Tutorial.

docs.title: Delete this environment Section
docs.text:
This section allows you to delete the environment and everything it contains.

To delete the environment, click the red "Delete environment" button.

WARNING: This action is irreversible. Ensure you want to delete the environment before proceeding.

docs.title: Export
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to export backups. Backups serve as essential data insurance, ensuring quick recovery and minimal operational overhead in the face of data loss or system failures.

docs.title: Accessing the Backups tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select "Backups".

docs.title: Exporting a Backup
docs.text:
1. Click on the arrow drop down list next to the "Restore" button in the right corner
  2. Click on the "Download DB" button to download backup database
  3. Click on the "Download files" buton to download backup files

docs.title: Import
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to import backups in different environments. Backups serve as essential data insurance, ensuring quick recovery and minimal operational overhead in the face of data loss or system failures.

docs.title: Accessing the Backups tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select "Backups".

docs.title: Importing a Backup
docs.text:
1. Click the "Import locally" button in the right corner.
  1. Upload the backup file from your device in the tar.gz archive format.
  2. In the pop-up window include a comment and click the "Import" button.
  1. Once the file is loaded, it will appear as the first backup in the list of backups.

docs.title: Manage
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to create and delete backups in different environments. Backups serve as essential data insurance, ensuring quick recovery and minimal operational overhead in the face of data loss or system failures.

docs.title: Accessing the Backups tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select "Backups".

docs.title: Creating a Backup
docs.text:
1. Click the "Create" button in the right corner.
  1. In the pop-up window:
    • Include a comment
    • Click the "Create" button
  2. The newly created backup will appear in the list of backups

docs.title: Nightly Backup
docs.text: The system automatically creates a backup at night. These backups appear with the "Nightly backup" comment in the list of backups.

docs.title: Deleting a backup
docs.text:
1. Click on the arrow drop down list next to the "Restore" button in the right corner.
  1. Click on the "Delete" button
  1. In the pop up window, click the "Delete" button to confirm the deletion of the backup.

docs.title: Restore
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to restore backups in different environments. Backups serve as essential data insurance, ensuring quick recovery and minimal operational overhead in the face of data loss or system failures.

docs.title: Accessing the Backups tab
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Environments tab.
  1. Choose the desired environment from the list.
  2. A new dropdown navigation menu will appear.
  3. In the left-side menu, select "Backups".

docs.title: Restoring a Backup
docs.text: NOTE: Before restoring a backup, make sure to stop the environment in which the application is running. To stop the application, follow the steps from the Actions tutorial.

docs.title: Restoring a backup in the same environment
docs.text:
1. Click the "Restore" button in the right corner.
  1. In the pop-up window include a comment and click the "Restore" button.
  1. Once the backup is restored, it will appear in the list of backups.

docs.title: Restoring a backup in a different environment
docs.text:
1. Click on the arrow drop down list next to the "Restore" button in the right corner.

  1. Select the environment from the drop down list to which you want to restore the backup.

  2. In the pop-up window include a comment and click the "Restore" button.

  1. Once the backup is restored, it will appear in the list of backups.

docs.title: Mendix
docs.text: This document guides you through creating and deploying new application versions in the Low-Ops platform using Mendix Studio Pro.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Mendix Studio Pro is a powerful low-code development environment that allows developers to rapidly build and customize enterprise-grade applications. This guide covers the entire process, from accessing the Git repository to making changes in Mendix Studio Pro and verifying them across different environments.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Access to the Low-Ops portal
  • Mendix Studio Pro installed on your machine

Note: For instructions on logging into the Low-Ops portal, refer to the Login tutorial.

docs.title: Access Git Repository
docs.text:
1. In the Low-Ops portal, navigate to the "Security" tab.
  2. Copy the Git repository URL.

docs.title: Open Project in Mendix Studio Pro
docs.text:
1. In Mendix Studio Pro, click the "Open Private App" button.
  1. In the pop-up window, paste the Git repository URL.
  2. Click "Connect", then "OK".

docs.title: Make Changes
docs.text:
1. In the "MyFirstModule" menu, select "Home_Web" from the dropdown list.
  1. Double-click the item you wish to modify.
  2. Make your desired changes and click "OK".

docs.title: Commit Changes
docs.text:
1. Click the "Commit" button, then "Save and Continue".
  1. In the pop-up window, describe your changes and click "OK".

docs.title: Check Activity
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Activity tab

Note: To learn how to access Activity tab, follow the steps from the Activities tutorial

  1. The status of the changes made will be "Completed".

docs.title: Access Environment
docs.text:
1. Go to the "Environments" tab and select an environment.
  1. In the left-side menu, go to "Access".

Note: To learn how to access "Access" tab, follow the steps from the Access tutorial

docs.title: Verify Changes in Mendix
docs.text:
1. Use the provided URL and login credentials to access Mendix Studio Pro.
  2. After logging in, you'll be directed to the Mendix home page where you can observe your implemented changes.

docs.title: Mendix 8 Support
docs.text:
Low-Ops platform utilizes private Git repositories to store Mendix application source code.

Mendix Studio Pro versions before 9 are compatible only with SVN (Version Control System) and do not support Git. Consequently, Git command line interface is employed for committing and pushing changes to remote repositories.

docs.title: Instructions:
docs.text:
• Begin by downloading and installing Git-Bash.
  • Use Git-Bash to clone the Mendix project repository.
  • Launch Mendix Studio Pro and click on "Open App".
  • Choose the "Locally on Disk" option.
  • Navigate to the directory where the project was cloned and select the .mpr file.
  • After making changes to your application, return to Git-Bash and commit and push the changes to the remote repository using Git commands.

docs.title: Login
docs.text: Low-Ops is an Internal Developer Platform (IDP) designed specifically for private cloud and on-premise deployments. It transforms your existing infrastructure into a secure, powerful platform for Mendix app development and deployment, all within your controlled environment.

docs.title: Logging in to Low-Ops Portal
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Low-Ops portal: https://portal.trial.low-ops.com/
  2. Click on the "Log in with SSO" button.
  1. Enter your username/email and password.
  1. Click on the "Log in" button.
  2. Once logged in, you will be redirected to the Low-Ops portal.

docs.title: No account?
docs.text: Contact platform administrator to get an account.

docs.title: Support
docs.text: This document provides instructions on how to request support in the Low-Ops Portal.

docs.title: Accessing Support
docs.text:
1. On the home page, locate the user menu in the upper right corner.

  2. Click the drop-down menu next to your user name.

  1. In the drop-down menu, click on "Support".

  3. In the support request form:

Note: Our support department will review your request and get back to you to resolve your issue or address your request.

docs.title: Best Practices for Submitting Support Requests
docs.text:
• Be as specific as possible in describing your issue or request
  • Include any relevant error messages
  • Mention any steps you've already taken to try to resolve the issue
  • Provide context about the importance or urgency of your request

docs.title: Portal Administration
docs.text: This document provides an overview of the administration interface in the Low-Ops Portal and instructions on managing users, teams, and applications.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Administration section in the Low-Ops Portal allows administrators to: - View all users in the portal - Create new users - Manage application access - Oversee teams and applications - Monitor activity

This centralized administration area enables efficient user management and control over platform resources.

docs.title: Accessing the Administration Section
docs.text:
1. Log in to the Low-Ops portal.
  2. Navigate to the "Administration" tab in the upper left corner.

docs.title: Managing Users
docs.text:
1. In the left menu, select the "Users" tab.

docs.title: Resetting User Password
docs.text: Note: To learn how to reset a user's password, follow the steps in the Reset Password tutorial.

docs.title: High Level Architecture
docs.text: Low-Ops is made up of a set of components that work together to provide a platform for running applications.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
There are 3 main layers in Low-Ops architecture:

  1. Applications - Custom-built applications that run on Low-Ops.
  2. Platform - The platform that runs the applications. It also provides a diverse set of services that are used by the applications or enables developers to build, deliver, and own their applications end-to-end.
  3. Foundation - The foundation that the platform runs on. This is the cloud provider or on-premise datacenter that provides a cloud-agnostic foundation which must be a Kubernetes cluster.

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text:
Deploying components onto Kubernetes is not rocket science. However, having the platform to be reproducible, scalable, and maintainable is a challenge. Low-Ops is designed to be easy to use and requires minimal maintenance. It is designed to be used by developers and operators with minimal knowledge of Kubernetes and cloud infrastructure. You will be able to do all your tasks through the Low-Ops Portal supported with best practices of delivering applications to your business and customers.

Because the whole platform is fully automated and runs on your infrastructure, you have 100% control over your data and can be sure that it is secure. You can also easily integrate it with your existing systems and processes.

Don't want or need upgradability of Low-Ops? You can modify it to fit your needs. You can also use it as a starting point for your own platform.

docs.title: Platform Foundation
docs.text:
The platform foundation is an infrastructure level that has to provide a scalable, flexeble and extensible enviromnemt for the platform lifecycle. To build the platform foundation, you can use cloud providers or on-premise solutions that allow you to run managed or self-managed Kubernetes (k8s) clusters.

There are 2 different platform foundation_types:

  • generic - Default platform installation method supports any Kubernetes custom or managed solution. All platform components required to run future applications workloads will be installed automatically.

  • aws - Optimised platform installation for AWS-specific services natively supports other AWS services such as EKS, RDS, S3, ELB, EBS. To use AWS-managed data resources, you need to create them before platform installation as part of the foundation setup. Refer to the diagram bellow for more details.

High level AWS diagram:

docs.title: Platform Configuration
docs.text:
Before starting the platform installation process, check the configuration options below. Change required paramaters to match your environment setup.

Create values file values.yaml with following parameters:

For more advanced configuration and options descriptions follow this page

lowops:
  image:
    containerImage: registry.gitlab.com/cinaq/low-ops-platform/ansible-roles:0-ci-v3-1-2

  # LowOps platfrom configuration variables
  config:
    common:
      base_domain: ci.cinaq.com
      platform_state: present
      foundation_type: generic
      email_domain: cinaq.com
      general_client_name: CINAQ
      platform_version: v3.1.2
    ingress:
  # Update certificate and key params values to base64 encoded strings 
      default_ssl_cert: base64-encoded-cert-string
      default_ssl_key: base64-encoded-key-string

docs.title: Configure Namespace
docs.text:
Run script below to create deployment job namespace. Add pull secret to the namespace. 

NAMESPACE=lowops-devops
kubectl create namespace "$NAMESPACE"

UPSTREAM_REGISTRY="registry.gitlab.com"
UPSTREAM_REGISTRY_USER="registry-user" # change with your resgitry user
UPSTREAM_REGISTRY_TOKEN="registry-token" # change with your registry password
UPSTREAM_REGISTRY_AUTH=$(echo -n "$UPSTREAM_REGISTRY_USER:$UPSTREAM_REGISTRY_TOKEN" | base64)

mkdir -p /tmp/lowops-docker-config
echo "
{
    \"auths\": {
        \"$UPSTREAM_REGISTRY\": {\"auth\": \"$UPSTREAM_REGISTRY_AUTH\"}
    }
}
" > /tmp/lowops-docker-config/config.json

# ensure lowops-registry secret exists
kubectl -n "$NAMESPACE" create secret generic lowops-registry --from-file=.dockerconfigjson=/tmp/lowops-docker-config/config.json --type=kubernetes.io/dockerconfigjson

docs.title: Install metallb
docs.text:
Note: This step is not needed for managed k8s solutions.

Add bitnami helm repo

helm repo add "bitnami" "https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami"
helm repo update

Install metallb chart

# Network pool must be accesseble from cluster.
START_NETWORK=172.20.255.200
END_NETWORK=172.20.255.250
helm upgrade -i -n metallb --create-namespace metallb bitnami/metallb \
    --version 3.0.12 \
    --set "configInline.address-pools[0].name=default" \
    --set "configInline.address-pools[0].protocol=layer2" \
    --set "configInline.address-pools[0].addresses[0]=${START_NETWORK}-${END_NETWORK}" \
    --set "speaker.secretValue=stronk-key"

docs.title: Install Platform
docs.text:
From the deploy server with access to the Kubernetes cluster API. Install the platform by installing lowops helm chart.

Add lowops helm repository.

helm repo add --username $UPSTREAM_REGISTRY_USER --password $UPSTREAM_REGISTRY_TOKEN lowops \
    "https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/41532268/packages/helm/stable"

helm repo update

Run helm install command to start the platform setup process.

NAMESPACE=lowops-devops
CHART_VALUES_FILE=values.yaml
CHART_VERSION=0.1.407
HELM_CMD="helm upgrade -i lowops-platform lowops/lowops -n $NAMESPACE"
if [ -f "$CHART_VALUES_FILE" ]; then
    HELM_CMD="$HELM_CMD -f $CHART_VALUES_FILE"
fi
if [ -n "$CHART_VERSION" ]; then
    HELM_CMD="$HELM_CMD --version=$CHART_VERSION"
fi
echo "$HELM_CMD"
eval "$HELM_CMD"

After deploy job started you can get installation log

kubectl logs -n lowops-devops --timestamps=true job/lowops-platform -f

After deploy finished successfully start with exploring LowOps platform portal. In browser access https://portal.ci.cinaq.com (where ci.cinaq.com is your base domain.)

docs.title: Light Version
docs.text: The light version of the Low-Ops platform allows you to run Low-Ops on a single Linux machine, making it ideal for testing purposes.

docs.title: Required Packages
docs.text:
Ensure the following binaries are installed on the machine with access to the Kubernetes API before starting:

  • kubectl - Version v1.27
  • helm - Version v3.9
  • kind - Version v1.27

docs.title: Kubernetes Cluster
docs.text:
The Low-Ops platform requires a Kubernetes cluster. Currently supported Kubernetes versions are:

  • v1.27
  • v1.28
  • v1.29

docs.title: System Resources
docs.text: To run the platform, the system should have at least 16 GB of RAM and an 8-core CPU.

docs.title: Platform Foundation
docs.text: This setup requires a single Linux server with internet access and Docker installed.

docs.title: Step 1: Install Kubernetes Cluster
docs.text:
Create a kind-config.yaml configuration file with the following content:

kind: Cluster
apiVersion: kind.x-k8s.io/v1alpha4
nodes:
- role: control-plane
- role: worker
- role: worker
- role: worker
networking:
  apiServerPort: 6443
  apiServerAddress: 0.0.0.0

Create the Kubernetes cluster on the Linux server. Replace dev with your company or project name:

kind create cluster --name dev --config ./kind-config.yaml --image "kindest/node:v1.27.3" -v 1

Retrieve the Kubernetes configuration from the created cluster:

kind get kubeconfig --name=dev > ~/.kube/config

docs.title: Step 2: Install Proxy (Required Only for Light Platform Installation)
docs.text:
Create an haproxy.cfg file with the following content:

global
    log stdout format raw local0 info

defaults
    log global
    retries 2
    option dontlognull
    timeout connect 10000
    timeout server 600000
    timeout client 600000

frontend http_frontend
    bind *:80 
    default_backend http_backend

frontend https_frontend
    bind *:443 
    default_backend https_backend

backend https_backend
    server nginx-ingress 172.19.255.200:443 check send-proxy

backend http_backend
    server nginx-ingress 172.19.255.200:80 check send-proxy

Start the HAProxy service using the following command:

docker run -d \
    --restart unless-stopped \
    --name haproxy \
    --network=kind \
    -v $(pwd)/haproxy.cfg:/usr/local/etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg:ro \
    -p 443:443 \
    -p 80:80 \
    haproxytech/haproxy-alpine:2.4

For further steps, please refer to the main installation page.
